div.head: Alexandria Horse Show.
div.p: A Horse Show will be held on the A.S.C. grounds on Saturday, April 18, commencing at 9 a.m.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe, via Port Said and Brindisi, will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, At 3.10 p.m' on Sunday.

div.head: Cattle Plague:
div.p: Ten cases of cattle plagne were reported last week from the districts of Mellawi, Tantah, Fashn, and Beni Mazar.

div.head: Automobile-Club.
div.p: The inaugural ball of the Cairo Automobile Club will he held on the 18th. inst. at 10 p m. Six hundred invitations have already been issued.

div.head: Mendiolty In Calro.
div.p: The Cairo City Police arrested 59 mendicants last month 31 of them have been warned that should they resume begging they will be treated as vagabonds.

div.head: Fayoum Province
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior intends to divide the Fayoum province into five instead of three districts as the province is larger now than formerly was the case. It is to be hoped that this new arrangement will improve the conditions of public security there. Burnt to Death. * A child of Sohag, aged 5, who was left by his mother near a fire, was burnt to death yesterday, his clothes having caught alight. The distracted mother tried to save her child's life by pouring water on him, but it was too late. He succumbed to his injuries.

div.head: Bubonic Plague.
div.p: Eight cases of plague were reported yesterday, with 5 deaths. Last week's bulletin reports 70 fresh cases, an increase largely due, according to the Public Health Department, to the neglect or delay of the local authorities (onidebs, etc.) in reporting; cases to the Sanitary inspectors.

div.head: Burglary at Calro.
div.p: For the fourth time the Nasrieh branch of the firm of Nicolas Soussa Fr res, in Rue el Dawarwin, Cairo, has been broken into, The establishment of these cigarette manufæoturers is in a frequented street and near a ghaffir's station. The robbers took the money in the cashbox as well as a large stock of cigarettes.

div.head: Motor Car Accidents.
div.p: Chakour Pasha's motor car, in charge of a Greek chauffeur, ran over a native opposite the Café Chicha in Kamel Street, Cairo, on Wednesday. Another accident occurred in the same street on that day when a motor car, No. 295, ran over a native, who dashed across the street in front of it, the wheels passing over his body. The man's condition is almost hopeless.

div.head: Agricultural Show.
div.p: The following are the numbers of the visitors who went to the recent Agricultural Show at Ghezireh. 1st day, 1,311 ; 2nd day, 2,988; 3rd day, 2,315; 4th day, 6, 109; 5th day, 3,289 ; or a total of 15,962 entrances with payment. There were also 6,000 cards of admission given to members of the Agricultural Society and a number of cards giving a right of permanent entry. The total number of visitors is estimated at 30,000, which is a record.

div.head: Annual Military Tournament.
div.p: The annual Military Tournament will be held on the Observatory Ground on Thursday, 21st inst. There will be an enclosure reserved for officers of the rank of Yusbashi and upwards and civilian employés, situated on the left of the Khedivial enclosure, and admission to same will be by ticket (except for officers in uniform). There will also be an enclosure for the friends of officers and civilian employés. Admission to this enclosure will also be by ticket, and the number of tickets will be limited to three for each officer and civilian employé.

div.head: FATHY BEY'S APPOINTMENT.
FOREIGN SECRETARY AND LORD CROMER.
TRUSTING THE "MAN ON THE SPOT."
div.p: London, Friday.

In the House of Commons Mr Dillon asked if Lord Cromer had been consulted regarding 'sel Fathy Bey Zagloul's appointment, and whether tic Sir Edward Grey's attention was directed to the effect on public opinion of the appointment, so soon after the Denishwai trial.
Sir Edward Grey: " That is a point on which G, I have perfect confidence in the discretion of his tio Majesty's Representative."

Pressed further, Sir E. Grey said that Lord Cromer was very likely consulted regarding, most of these appointments, and if so he had no intention of questioning Lord Cromer's conclusions. (Cheers) Sir E. Grey had received 18 one protests against the appointment purporting du to be signed by 31 persons.

div.head: THE FALL IN CONSOLS.
div.p: Although Consols were an uneasy market cel during the whole of last year, the tendency as being generally downward, they never managed to touch the present abnormal figure. The ke highest price last year was 91, on the sati fac- Co ktory ending of the Algeciras Conference in April. The lowest price was during last October, 8, which occurred on the advance of the Bank rate to 6 per cent. The previous lowest point was attained in 1904, when the Russians fired on the British trawlers. The previous lowest records within recent years was 84 & in 1866, when over-speculation ended in panic, the Bank Act being suspended and the Bank rate was at 10 per cent.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive attended midday prayer to- The day at Montazah mosque. His Highness will leave Alexandria this evening for Cairo.
The Council of Ministers will probably be held at Abdeeni on Monday under the presidency of the Khedive.

div.head: THE GHAZI'S REPORTS.
div.p: Nuri Bey, first secretary to Ghazi Mukhtar.co Pasha, Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner for in Egypt, left Cairo on Wednesday for de Constantinople, where he will remain for four weeks. It is stated that Nuri Bey is entrusted with some important reports from his master to the Mabein and the Sublime Port.

div.head: THE GRANDMOULIN AFFAIR.
div.p: The Journal du Caire" contains a biting article from the pen of M. G. Vayssié on the ne attacks made by the 'Egyptian Standard" on M. Grandmoulin, from which we take the following extracts : - - "One may expect the delegate of Egyptian thought-Mustapha Pasha Kamel—to express a different opinion from that of the rest of mortals. When one has received a celestial!.. message one must indulge in signs and wonders . for the public benefit ... The depository be of all the national dignity had for too long as excited no attention. Such a state of things could not last The Pasha does not care to preach in the desert The slightest incident and he darts up a minaret to wave his arms above the multitude. This time the shouting dervish of 'Al Lewa' has had a visit from the Angel Gabriel and the angel said : 'A European has killed a child, not by accident as the world believes, but wilfully. Avenge us !'... Mustapha is now on his way to accomplish this pleasant task. Driving straight ahead like the national "famous' he excites the public at street corners. . . The jest has been pushed too far." .

"Slowly, systematically, Mustapha Pasha Kamel widens the gulf between us and the natives : insidiously and bitterly he aims atli. provoking the conflict from which his immeasurable vanity leads him to hope to fish out some ill-gotten gains. ... . His words do not matter, his acts alone count, and they are full of violence and ill faith."
"Meantime one can only meet him with the calm kindness of reason tKat we employ in the presence of madness. Any other attitude can only serve the aims of an unprincipled adversary.

*B t Mustapha Pasha and his handful of an madmen must not forget that there are laws-- | in Teven for the insane. And if I were M. Grand-th moulin, in default of an asylum where they might be caged, I would remind all these ge worthies who have escaped from the School of du Law that words may be winged, but damages come to stay."

"Al Moayad," in an article on the affair, considers that the incident shows the necessity for overhauling the system of capitulations by enlarging the scope of the Mixed Courts in order to make them able to deal with criminal matters.

CAIRO & ALEXANDRIA.
London, Thursday.

A small parliamentary deputation, consisting of a few Members of Parliament, including Mr. J. M. Robertson and Sir William Brampton Gurdon, privately interviewed the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs and urged him to grant certain concessions in the direction of a "self-government for Egypt. No official information has transpired in reference to the terms of Sir Edward Grey's reply..
LONDON, Friday.

It is officially denied to-day that Sir Edward | Grey gave a sympathetic reply to the deputation asking for Home Rule for Egypt, or that he made any new statement of policy in regard to Egyptian affairs.

Sir William Brampton Gurdon, K.C.M.G, C.B, has been M.P. for North Norfolk since 1899. He has come prominently before the public lately in regard to the Bill for marriage with a deceased wife's sister, which he has i promoted. He was born in 1840, and married a daughter of the Earl of Portsmouth. He wast private secretary to Mr Gladstone as Chancellor of the Exchequer in 1865-66 and as Prime Minister from 868 to 1874. Hen owns about 3,000 acres in Norfolk and is a keen farmer. Last year he was chairman of the Committee of Selection in the House of Commons

div.head: ENGLISHMAN DROWNED IN HARBOUR.
div.p: Mr. George Neill, an old British resident in Alexandria, who was formerly chief engineer of Messrs. Choremi Benachi's cotton press at Minet-el-Bassu], and was latterly employed by the Société de Pressage et des Dépôts, met This death by drowning this morning, having it fell into the sea from the quay at Alexandria. The exact circumstances of Mr. Neill's death are not known, but an enquiry has been opened.

div.head: BRITISH BEER BREWERIES (EGYPT), LIMITED.
div.p: The erection of the brewery of the above his company at Choubra is rapidly being pushed forward, and unless some at present unforeseen c delay is caused, the company should be ready h to commence operations about July 1st next to

The foundations are of the compressol type, I which will guarantee against any possible damage owing to high Nile. The superstructure is of a most substantial character, being entirely composed of masonry, steel work and cement. The directors are of the opinion that the building will be completed by 3 st May next, and may be completed earlier, as the contractor is under a heavy penalty in case of delay beyond that date. The machinery and plaut have been bought and are now on their way from England. The water of the well, which is 43 metres in depth, is of an exceptionally good quality for brewing purposes.

Mr. Walter King, the chief brewer of the # company, is now in this country, and after studying the qualities and prices of beer in use here, expresses the opinion that the company can more than hold its own in the trade, both in quality and price, especially in the latter, and that it is in possession of a business which will yield very large profits. In the opinion of the directors, the market for the products has considerably increased since the company was incorporated, and the directors have received assurances of support from some of the largest users of stout, ales, and beer in Egypt, some of whom are interested in the company.

div.head: THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY.
THE COPTIC PETITION.
div.p: The fact that a number of representative Copts have sent a petition to the British | Agency deprecating the extraordinary resolutions of the General Assembly has roused a great deal of indignation among the Moslem Nationalist Press. The petition of these Copts has come at a highly inconvenient moment, for as they represent the ancient inhabitants of the country it is impossible to treat them as "intrus." The alarm of the Copts at the pretensions of the General Assembly is very reasonable for they are well aware what their position would be if ever the Moslem Nationalists attained to political power. "Al Minbar" at first feigned to believe that the Copts, who were party to this petition, were mere nobodies, but in its yesterday's issue that Nationa ist organ has to admit that one of the framers of the petition was the proprietor of the representative Coptic daily newspaper in Egypt, Tadros Bey Shenouda el Mangabardi

The British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt is also taken to task by the Anglophobe vernacular Press because that institution ventured to pass a resolution to the effect that any material change in the existing system of administration would be a serious blow to the moral and financial prosperity of Egypt.
"Al Ahram" remarks :

"It has become very clear now that there are two forces struggling in Egypt. One is national, the other financial. The demands advanced the other day by the Assembly led to the rising of the financiers, who said to the Egyptians,
Avoid asking for your natural rights and be patient enough to bear the present oppression without showing disappointment and pain.'

The British Chamber of Commerce clamourel loudly and complained saying that such demands if put in force would be very dangerous. But we were not astonished at this move. nient, for this chamber and others think that they are the true sovereigns of Egypt and no one has to take part in directing the machine or the state with them.
"Such is the way the foreign financiers, merchants and all those who earn a living under the patronage of the present administration, follow in treating us."

*Al Ahram" in another article says :-"We know that the Times has always been the weapon of the financiers of London who sought to choke our aspirations, but now another hero rises -- the British Chamber of Commerce of Alexandria. Frankly we are not surprised. Cecil Rhodes and his followers have taught us how high finance can rend a small nation to slake its ferocious thirst for blood. These are not the days of Chamberlain and his. troupe and we trust in the liberal spirit of the present British Government."

div.head: EGYPTIAN ETHNOLOGY.
div.p: At the last meeting of the Anthropological Institute of London, held on the 26th ult., Dr C. S. Myers read a paper on "The Ethnology of Modern Egypt." The measurements, notes, and photographs taken in this investigation led to the conclusion (1) that, compared with the "prehistoric" people of 5000 BC, the modern inhabitants show no sensible difference ia head measurements or in the degree of satter of individual measurements about their average ; (2) that the modern Copts throughout Egypt are less negroid than the modern Moslem population ; (3) that both the Copts and the Moslems in Upper Egypt are more negroid than those in Lower Egypt; and (4) that from the anthropometric standpoint there is no evidence of plurality of race in modern Egypt.

div.head: EGYPT AND BABYLONIA.
div.p: The Rev. A.H. Sayce, in his new work on the archæology of the cuneiform inscriptions, devotes much time and attention , to the parallels between Babylonian and Tigyptian civilization. He admits that he is prepossessed in favour of a Semitic origin for the culture of Egypt because, when "the patronage of the Berlin Egyptologists had rot yet made it fashionable," he asserted that the Egyptian language belonged to the Seritic family of speech. In addition to the evidence of the brick, its stamp, and the cylinder seal in favour of this supposed derivation, he mentions the fresh witness of clay sealings on Babylonian jars "exactly like those of early Egypt." The "Athenæum".comngents on this assertion as follows : '' we have looked through the article in the Recueil de Pravaux to which he referred us in support of 1 this assertion, and we can find nothing like un Egyptian jar-sealing, the only jar there represented as closed having a stopper like cork. A better parallel, which he mentions in another connexion, but which does not appear to have struck him, is the fact that, on his authority, Sumerian chairs terminated with curved legs resembling those of an ox, which is exactly the characteristic of the furniture found by M. Amélineau in the First Dynasty tombs at Abydos. Yet if all these parallelisms could be established beyond dispute, there is nothing in them, except per3, naps the use of clay, which cannot be explained ° as due to conscious or unconscious borrowing rather than to derivation ; whilo most of the | supposed identities in the ideograms of the two nations put forward by Prof. Hommel 16 I are, pace Prof. Sayoe, too far fetched to be convincing."

div.head: PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT.
THE ALLEGED SCANDALS.
div.p: Mr. C. H. Moore telegraphs to us this morning from Zeitoun requesting us to state that he is instituting legal proceedings for libel against all the local newspapers and persons who have made false statements against him in reference to the alleged scandals in the Public Works Department. He also informs us that be has not been asked to resign from his official position in that Department.n

div.head: FELLATA IN THE SUDAN.
div.p: It is estimated that during the last twelve months no less than five thousand of the Fellata have entered the Sudan. The "Sudan Gazette" states that this race is always on the move eastwards. Their chief aim seems to be a pilgrimage to Mecca and Medina Some-1 times they spend some twelve years between the time they leave their homes and the day they reach their goal.

Those of them who reached the Sudan have been very well treated by the Government. A large number under the son of one of their te Emirs were assisted to continue their pilgrim: B age. A good many of them are, between, lis settling in the country and in this way materially add to the labour supply which at K no time has been superfluous. As they are yo generally well behaved and law-aiding their of advent should be desirable.'

'They have not, it is true, been accustomed to any work aud they are said to be slow in their labours, but they can he easily trained to do the unskilled town or country work and 4g they have been very useful at Omdurman in drawing water and as porters.
Their engagement in agricultural labour has brought the native labourers to their senses and a semblance of keen competition promises G to arise in the near future.

American Futures The market opened this week quietly but gradually became stronger, and stimulated by foreign buying orders prices have hardened and gathered the strength, notwithstanding several sets-back. There has also been considerable "Bull" mani. the population in New York, such operations being 9 rendered more feasible at present owing to the limited supply of- fel ing. The recent unsatisfactory deliveries against purchases of 1 actual cotton in the south have cau ed imDB porters to stop buying and our market has d thus been deprived of its usual amount of G "hedges.'' Towards the close of this week the bullish feeling has been increased by Mr. Theodore Price's strong circulars, and the closing prices shewa general advance of 13 5 points since last Thursday.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Among the latest arrivals at the Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley, aro Prince and Princess E. Livaff and daughter.
Lady Ulrica Baring is expected at Little Esher Place, Esher, shortly from Egypt, where she has been staying for some time past.
Sir John Harrington will not return to Abyssinie for at least five or six months, if not for a longer period.
Mr: J. Wells, Inspector of Mines,' has . returned to Kenèh after a tour of inspection in the desert as far as Jebel el Zeit.

Mr. Wilfrid Ashley has returned to his house in Bruton St., his Parliamentary duties | having necessitated his return from Egypt. Mrs. Ashley accompanied bim as far as Paris on the return journey, and is now staying with her father, Sir Ernest Cassel, at Biarritz.

A marriage has been arranged, and will take place at the end of the year, between Brevet 'Major Cyril Wilson, Lancashire Fusic liars, Governor of Singa, Sudan, second son of the late Major-General Sir Charles Wilson, K.C.B., K.C.M.G., F.R.S., and Beryl Marie, younger daughter of Colonel W. Hunter Little, of Hyde Lodge, Winchester, and formerly commanding 1st East Lancashire Regiment.

div.head: FALL IN CONSOLS. THE CITY DEPRESSED

div.p: The fall in Consols is depressing the City. Fear is expressed that speculation in New York may cause a crash.
(Reuter)

An unprecedented selling on the Stock Market, owing to the banks calling in loans in view of heavy disbursements, caused a panic, . The Cabinet in Washington decided to postpone calling in 30,000,000 dollars deposited in the banks in order to relieve the monetary stringency.
(Reuter)

In view of the alarmist reports current yesterday in the City in consequence of the weakness of Consols, the "Times" remarks that this weakness is the inevitable accompaniment of a prolonged spell of dear money, high prices of commodities, and activity of trade, and is in itself a highly satisfactory symptom. (Reuter)

div.head:
COERCION ACT.
GOVERNMENT PLEDGED TO REPEAL.

div.p: House of Commons. -The Nationalist motion, supported by the Government, urging the repeal of the Coercion Act, was adopted *** by 252 votes to 83. * Mr. Birrell said that the Government was pledged to abolish this tyrannical code, which it had already suspended, but that the time was unsuitable to repeal it in view of the possibility of conflict with the Lords, also in view of the programme of Irish legislation which he hoped to introduce after Easter. (R)
House or Commons. — Sir H CampbellBannerman stated that Parliament would adjourn from 27th March to 8th April. (R.)
It is understood that it has been definitely settled that the question of the delimitation of armameuts is to be submitted for discussion to the Hague Conference. (Reuter)

The San Francisco school-board has notified President Roosevelt of the withdrawal of the order segregating Japanese school children. The President will accordingly to-day sign an order enforcing restrictions on the immigration of Japanese. (Reuter)
The Duke of Cumberland has protésted against the decision of the Diet of Brunswick to elect a Regent which excludes the Duke from the succession.. (Reuter)
Sig. Orlando has been appointed Minister of Justice. (llaras)
While the police were searching the students lodgings at Kharhoff a bomb exploded killing four gendarmerie officer, 3 policemen, and 2 civilians and injuring 6 persons. (Reuter)
. A train has been wrecked at Alkmar. Eleven persons were killed. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE IENA DISASTER.
SUGGESTION OF FOUL PLAY.

div.p: The " Journal des Debats " hints at the possibility of fhu play being the cause of ti catastrophe to the "Iena." The Toulon paper describe the fire which was still burning ye terday despite the vessel being flooded. T violence of the flames astonished the nav experts as the hull was almost incombustible even the plates seeined to burn. (Reuter)

According to the latest official reports 11 men perished in the disaster of the Iena. The suggestion of foul play is based on the fact that the accident occurred in the ster where the officers' cabins were. The Minister of Marine announces that is feared that the Iena is a total loss. (Reuter)
The President of the Republic, M. Clemeceau, and General Picquast will attend the funeral at Toulon on Saturday of the 107 bodies which have been recovered. .
It is believed that the catastrophe was caused by the spontaneous combustion of the powder,
After speeches of condolence by the presidents, the Chamber and Senate suspended the sitting. (Наvаs)

div.head:
DISTURBANCES AT BELGRADE.
POLICE FIRE ON STRIKERS.

div.p: A strike of factory hands has taken place The strikers attacked the police who were escorting non-members of the union. Th police fired, killing 5 and wounding 20 Th strikers then marched in procession with the dead bodies to the House of Parliament "which they attempted to invade They afterwards attempted to carry them to the Palace (Reuter)
In a collision between strikers and the police three persons were killed. (Havas)

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We. do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but would wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits for discussion.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN STANDARD".
div.p: To the EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

The motto of this paper inculcates hospitality and freedom at home. Now the occupying English are the guests of Egypt, invited by the Khedive Tewfik. Had the English evacuated the country after restoring the Khedivial Authority, not they but the Sudanese (a blach race) would now be ruling Egypt, which would have been detrimental to the Egyptians' liberty and parliamentary aspirations, and, if only fox this reason, England can claim further hospitality from Egypt. Has any responsible Englishman ever said that England intends to annex Egypt

Let Egypt look at the Transvaal Constitution, the youngest offspring of the Mother of Parliaments, and remember that all things come to those who wait. As for freedom at home, Egypt has never been free and has always been ruled by an autocracy, and the Egyptian himself is naturally despotic. How does the rich Egyptian rule his Daira ? In in fact, English tutelage is the only hope of eventual freedom in Egypt. A class of men capable of governing by representative institutions takes time to evolve. Men of this class are still too scarce in Egypt to render constitutional methods of Government advisable. The ellah is not an ideal elector, but he has advanced somewhat of late years. An incident witnessed the other day tends to prove this. m passing through a village I heard a matrouh scream to a girl, "You daughter of a Log 1 how many times have I told you to keep hat sick fowl away from the healthy ones" Old residents will know that this is an immense stride towards the practical good of the country, for, a few years ago, the sick fowl would have been left with the others and any resulting death? woald have been pat down to fate. On looking back on the plagues, cholera smallpox, and falnines which used to ravage Egypt, and, on this general i sanitary condition of the village in the old days, they will see that the poorët classes of Egyptians have improved somewhat under English tutelage Also consider hon favourably the modern Egyp tian official compares with his predecessor of some years ago. It has been the will of Gor the | that circumstances have constrained England to be a somewhat staying, guest ; but she has ers tried to repay Egyptian hospitality by helping her towards freedom. Lord Oromer has been Che lent to Egypt when his valuable services might have been employed in settling the Irish question or some similar Imperial problem.

div.head: EGYPTIAN INVESTMENT AND AGENCY, LIMITED
div.p: To The EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,: The report of the directors of the Egyptian Investment and Agency, Limited, for the year 1906 is not cheerful reading for the holders of the only shares which are ne en- gotiable in' Egypt and which are virtually che fully paid, although by an ingenious mani07 population they are only credited with 5s., the balance of 159. per share being held by the 218. 'Anglo-Egyptian Bank in trust against the che unpaid ljábility. The directors have never explained why an application was not made esi- ' at the time of issue for a quotation on the London Stock Exchange for the different 28), denominations of shares, viz., partly and fully paid. Had this course been adopted the large sum now held in trust at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank would have been freed to earn profits for the company; and as the amount is reported to be about one-half of the entire authorised capital of the company, it would probably have earned sufficient to pay an extra shilling per share dividend. ce.

It may be safely asserted that the shareholders in Egypt never contemplated this heavy he i lock-up of capital to yield nothing to the company, but believed that it was only a he temporary convenience for Bourse settlement at, and that with the splendid opportunities are offered for the investment of capital here cen. the directors would have called up the balance -r) of the unpaid capital on all the shares within a reasonable period. Unless, however, the proprietors in Egypt unite to bring pressure on the London Board we shall witness the continuance of the present whimsical declarations of dividends.

Now as to the Profit and Loss Account. The gross profit earned for 1906 amounts roughly to £19,500, of which £12,400 results from profits on investments. As the net balance of the profit is £13,800 it appears that, apart from the profit derived from investments, always fluctuating and uncertain source of income, the result of the year's trading is just £1,400 - by no means a brilliant result.

The report refers to a further surplus over the cost of investments amounting to £30,000 S as per recent valuation. It is probable that to-day this amount shows a considerable dimin. Is the solution, and the issue of companies promoted 11 by this concern has not been attended with sufficient success to warrant the expectation j of any important benefit from this source in the future. Therefore if the directors continue in their fatuous policy of trying to work on the present unsatisfactory basis of capital the prospects of the concern appear dis inctly unpromising – I am, etc.

div.head: COMMERCIAL INDUSTRIAL & LAND COMPANY OF EGYPT, LTD.
div.p: To the EDITOŘ OF THE "ÉGYPTIAN GAZETTE". n

Sir, --The attention of my directors has been called to an article in a recent issue of na new Cairo morning newspaper, signed "Share holder," wherein certain references are made s to my company In order to dispel any misunder- standing, will you permit me to state that the e options acquired by my company were trans: referred to the Commercial Co. on exactly the same terms as they were obtained. My company had no voice whatever in respect of the acquisition of one or all of them, but it certèinly was our desire that the whole of the properties should be dealt with. Unfortunately the Commercial directors were of the opinion that certain of the properties were too highly priced and acquired only what they considered was in the direct interest of the shareholders. Is this & policy to which the most exacting shareholder can take exception?

As to the cash payment to my company, it did not cover the heavy expenses which the flotation entailed, but my directors are satisfied that the shares which were allotted to this company will, in the near future, materially appreciate in value.

My directors are aware that an attractive offer has been made for the freehold land at Boulac on which Messrs. Kuster's premises stand. It must therefore be apparent that apart! from the earning power of the Commercial. Company, che proceeds of the sale of the Boulac land would place the directors in a position to make a substantial distribution on the fully paid-up shares of the company. This may be detected sooner than many anticipate. The correspondent states that "the prospects are indeed encouraging" and we quite agree with him.
The directors of the Commercial Company are, we understand, making the necessary arrangements for the settlement and quotation referred to. I am, etc
div.byline: A. de Vere Hunt, The Westminster Industrial and Finance Developments, Ltd.

div.head: CAIRO BILLIARD TOURNAMENT.
div.p: A considerable number of people, among whom were several ladies, were present to witness the second round of the billiard tournament between the markers of Cairo hotels, this taking place at the Ghezireh Palace Hotel and Flowers being "at-home" to Peroy and Syer.

In the first game the opponents were Flowers and Syer, the former receiving a start of 76. Flowers get well away at the start and, having much the best o the luck, | while the balls were running very badly for the sørateh man, gained an easy victory. Throughout the game the breaks- were small and Syer proved quite unable to do himself justice with the ivory balls on a strange table, | he being accustomed to bonzoline balls. .. | The second game, that between Flowers and Perey, was much more evenly contested and I look not so one-sided. Percy eventually I won by 39, an excess of 14 over the handicap, but the only breaks of note were 49 by Percy and 80 and 23 by Flowers.

By his success on this occasion and owing I to Syers' second defeat Percy has secured for himself the championship this season, for having now won three games against the scores of Flowers' 1, and Syers' 0, and with only two more games to play, viz, Syer v. Peroy, and Syer v. Flowers, Percy cannot lose the tourne-: ment.

The third and final round of the tournament will be played at the Grand Continental Hotel on Wednesday, the 20th inst., and we look. - forward to seeing on this occasion Cairo's champion of last year revenging himself on his two opponents, for on this occasion he. will be playing on his own table and with the bonzoline balls to which he is accustomed.

In spite of the fact that the final result of I the tournament is now assured, great interest is still being shown, and it is anticipated that next Wednesday evening the billiard saloon of the Continental will be crowded with Syers' admirers and well-wishers. We are also informed that as a result of the game played between Percy and Syer in the first round of the tournament at Shepheard's Hotel, on which occasion Percy received 50 start, one of Percy's admirers has made a match for him to play Syer at even points on Shepheard's table and has put up a substantial sum for the winner.

div.head: RACES AT ZIGAZIG.
div.p: Very extensive preparations are being made for the forthcoming race meeting at Zagazin, and no expense is being spared to make it the biggest and it is to be hoped the most success. ful event of its kind over held in the provinces. There will be seating accommodation for nearly 1,000 spectators, a special train is being run from Cairo, and luncheon is being provided by the Cie. des Wagons-lits. In addition to this a special entertainment committee has been formed and is issuing invitations to all the heads of departments, moulders, and all inspectors connected with the province, together with their wives, to a private luncheon. The catering for this is in the same hands. Intending visitors must book their tables in advance with the Wagons Lits Co.
Tickets for the special train are on sale at all the hotels and clubs, and tourists should not miss this extremely interesting anl picturesque Bedouin gathering.

div.head: FAYOUM RACES.
div.p: The Fayoum race meeting will take place this afternoon. It promises to be a great success. Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, President of the Council of Ministers, accompanied by Ermolli Bey, arrived at Medinet el-Fayoum from Cairo yesterday and will attend the races this alter. noon, returning to Cairo to-morrow.

div.head: GYMKHANA.
div.p: A Gymkhana will be held at Mena House on Friday, 22nd inst, when tes will be sery. based on the ground free of charge, prizes! will be given for all the events, and a band! will play during the afternoon. The following is a list of events, which commence at 2.45 p.m.

row.cell: | 2.45.- Mena House Stakes. Donkey Race for Gentlemen. Distance i furlong without bridles. Entrance P.T. 5.- 2 Prizes, objets | d'arts.
3.00.- Gentlemen's Hack Race. Distance : mile. Entrance P.T. 10 – 2 Prizes, Objets d'Art.

3 30 -- Ladies' Hack Race. Distance 3 für. longs. Entrance P.T. 10— 2 Objets d'Art.
4.20.- The Mena Cup. For Arab hacks. Gentlemen up. Distance 5 furlongs. Entrance P.T. 10 — 2 Prizes.
4.40. --- The Donkey Derby. For Ladies and Gentlemen. Distance | mile. Entrance P.T. 5– 2 Prizes.
5.00.- Throwing the Tennis Ball. Ladies to ride & short distance on sponies and throw Tennis Balls to partner. Entrance P. T 5– 2 Prizes.

div.p: The following are the rules and conditions :

row.cell: 1. This meeting is held under K S.C. Rules.
2. In the event of any disputes the judge's decision shall be final.
3. No boys will be allowed on the course and spars are not permitted.
4. Entries should be made to the Secretary, Mena House Hotel, before 6 p.m. Thursday | 21st March Fees to be paid at the time of entry.
5. Entries can also be made for any event at the racecourse up to the time of starting on payment of entrance fee, plus P.T. 5.
6. In the event of more than twelve starting, the race may be ordered to be run in heats.

7. All the pony and horse races, are for bone fide hacks (a bona fide hack is a horse which has never raced at any meeting but a Gymkhana and is not kept for racing purposes nor kept in a raging stable).

div.head: ARMY AND NĀVY.
div.p: Colonel F. I. Maxse, C. B., D. 8. O., has been selected for command of the regiment of Coldstream Guards, vacant by the promotion of Colonel A. E. Codrington, O. B., to major general Colonel Maxse, who joined the Cold. streams from the Royal Fusiliers, in 1891, is now in command of the 2nd Battalion of the regiment at Aldershot.
Lieutenant Colonel C. J. Markham, King's Royal Rifle Corps, will be shortly promoted brevet colonel, on completing three years at the head of the 1st Battalion at Khartoum.

The command of the 2nd Battalion of the K, R. R. C., Jubbulpore, India, will become vacant in the coming autumn, by the retirement of Colonel W. S. Kaye 'under the four years rule. The step, it is expected, will go to Major Sir F. B. M. Henriker, Bart., second in command of the 4th Battalion.
Major A. S Koe, King's Own Scottish Borderers, has taken over the command of the Depot, Berwick-on-Tweed. Lieutenant Antrobus has also joined - for duty from the home battalion.

Captain E., C. Jennings, Royal Fusiliers, who was recently posted to the 3rd Battalion at Middleburg, Cape Colony, has retired to serve in the Militia under the usual conditions. Captain Jennings donned the busby in May, 1898, and got his company in 1902. He saw no war service,

It is intimated that from the 1st April next, the Depot of the Inniskilling Dragoons, Ballincollig, is to have an establishment of three officers, 10 sergeants, two trumpeters, six cor. porals, and 179 rank and Ale (including 25 old soldiers), total, 200 of all ranks, with 96 horses. In the future, it is to be known as the Provisional Depot.
There will be no changes in the artillery force in Egypt next relief season, according to the programme just issued.

The garrison of the " Rock" has been per. manently reduced by one battalion of infantry i the 2nd Battalion Royal Munster Fusiliers, which has just arrived home, and taken 'over quarters at Limerick-and 372 artillerymen. It is understood that further reductions in Colonial garrisons will be affected for the sake of economy

Mr. Haldane's proposals have created the greatest uneasiness in the Imperial Yeomanry, and his unwillingness to give the details for the future of the force has not done anything to allay that feeling. It is conceded on every side that any attempt to reduce the status of the Imperial Yeomanry will end disastrously.

It is now pretty well known that the gigantic Dreadnought has not realised expectations in several matters. In the first place, it is stated that she cannot be safely run over 16 knots per hour, which was the maximum speed on her trial run out to Trinidad recently, and secondly that her designs are not perfect. The latter can be remedied, and will be remedied in the new Dreadnoughts which are to be built under the estimates for the coming year. In many circles, the putting of the eggs into one huge basket is strongly deprecated, despite the fact that all the navies of the Continent and elsewhere are going in for Dreadnoughts. Even Brazil has ordered one, which will be able to accommodate half her navy. so far as the personnel is concerned.

div.head: 'Warning to the Printing Trade Re Linotype Machines.
div.p: It has come to the knowledge of Linotype and Machinery Lim ted, of London, that the |Linotype Company, of New York, U. 8. A., are offering their machines to Egyptian printer-, This is to caution all persons offering such machine for sale, or all persons intending to buy or who are boying the pame, that Linotype and Machinery Limited, of London, have the sole right to sell Ivory Machines in Egypt and the Soudan, and that all persons offering Mergenhuler Linotype Machines for sale in either of these countries, and all persons buying the same, will be prosecuted to the full extent of the law, and held liable in damages.
LINOTYPE & MACHINERY LIMITED,
London, England.

div.head: The National Hotels and Residences Co.
div.p: AVIS

Le Conseil d'Administration de la The NATIONAL HOTELS AND RESIDENCES COMPANY & l'honneur de porter à la connaissance des Actionnaires que l'Assemblée Générale extraordinaire tenue le mercredi 18 Février courant p ayant pas obtenu le quorum, une nouvelle réunion, aura lieu le Jeudi 91 Mars 19 7 8 4 b pures de l'après-midi à l'Hôtel National au Caire pour :

row.cell: 1. Del bérer sur des propositions faites par | les promoteurs d'une nouvelle Société Anglaise ayant pour objet de créer et exploiter des Hôtels en Egypte. Ces propositions tendent à In fasion de la Société des National Hotels and Residences Company avec la dite nouvelle Société ; et
2. donne, le 088 échéant, ad Conseil tous pouvoirs les plus étendus afin d'accepter et passer les arrangements relatifs à la fasion et en assurer l'exécution.

div.p: A cette Assemblée Générale les porteurs de parts de fondateurs pourront assister aux termes de l'Art. 27 des Statuts. | Log décisions qni seront prises par l'Assem. .blée seront valables quel que ne soit le nombre des actionnaires présents ou représentés. Les titres devront être déposés cinq jours avant la réunion dans les Banques suivantes : ANGLO EGYPTIAN BANK LIMITED, I NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT et' IM. IMPERIAL OTTOMAN BANK.
La Caire, le 4 Mars 1907.
Puur le Conseil d'administration,
Le Président,
237611 A. SABBAGH BEY.

Tous et Dako Byams) provenant de la démolition dudit fort. Ces pierres sont divisées en lots de 20 à 00 M3.

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'en. hère de 1% et déposer le 10 % de la valeur o la marchandise achetée au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement intégral å ls a18e Municipale le lendemain du jour d'adjudication. Ils auront à supporter les droits de carrère au profit de la ville et devront employer les pierres achetées dans un délai de dix purs sous peine de folle enchère pour compte de l'adjudicataire et de perte du déloc de Alexandrie, le 12 Mars 1907.

Le Caire, Jeudi 14 Mars 1907 La taux de l'escompte libre à Londre 'epoore monté hier de 1/8 à 5 1/8 pour cent agité de la tension monétaire déterminée l'état: du marché de New York. Aa Stc Exchange, le Copaolidé anglais à subir nouvelle baisse de 3/8 à 85. L'Unifiée est res avariée à 102. La National Bank a porda à 87 6/8 et l'Agricole autant à 9 1/8. La Dal est demeurée inchangée à 15 7/8. La Del Light a rétrogradé & 11. "
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Égyptien s'est maintenu di 745. La Banque d'Athènes renseignée à 182, ex-coupon évidemment.

Les coor peu encourageants des places e rigeants d'Occident, jointe à la tension mon taire à Londres et à la perspective d'or augmentation incessante du taux de l'escompte de la Banque d'Angleterre, nous ont valu, matin, au marché franchement mauvais. I plupart des titres traités, voire les meilleur ont largement payé leur tribut à la baisse, qui n'est pas due à des ca 0809 locales, mais non vient cette fois de loin : de New-York en lign droite et de Londres par ricochet.

Aussi bien il n'y a pas lieu de s'inquiéter contre mestre, d'autant plus que la debole di marché américain a battu son plein ces troi jours derniers et que le Stock Exchange.semblé avoir déjà pleinement escompté tous ses effort compris l'élévation possible du taux de l'escompte officiel à 5 1/2 og 6%
Une bonne reprise ne saurait donc tarder se produire : elle sera, d'ailleurs, précipitée par les rachats de la spéculation à découvert, on jugera bientôt prudent de se couvrir.

Dans le compartiment des Banque, la National, relativement très éprouvée, étant donnée l'approche de paiement du coupon et de la nouvelle émission, & per fa 3/3 à 27 1/4. L'Agricole, fortement soutenue par des achats de placement intelligents, s'est maintenue fermement à 9. La Cassa di Sconto a fléobi à 227228 l'action ancienne, à 225-226 la nouvelle, et à 215 la dernière émission. La Banque d'Athènes s'est tassée à 183-134. Le Comptoir Financier a faibli à 6 7/8 15/16.

Le Crédit Foncier s'est raffermi à 741. L. Daïra s'est alourdie à 15 11/16-3/4 L'Agricole da Nil a recalé, à 250. L'Enterprise and Development a été mieux tenue à 11 5/8; par contre, sa part a baissé à 19 3/4.
Les Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux ont légèrement réactionné à 7 7/8-8 et leur part à 115-116. L'Epargne Immobilière est restée à 3 18/06 et la part à 125.
Bo excellente tendance, l'Expreng Nile & gagné environ 3/4 de livre à 5 3/4-6 l'action ancienne; la nouvelle & avancé à 4 3/4.5; la part a tardé à 145.
La Delta Light a fléchi 11, le: Jouissances Baux da Caire à 269 et les Cimenta à 40.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, 188 Nan Govich sont revenus & 28 3/8. Les Egyptian ont laissé près d'une livre et quart à 10 9/166/8. Les Upper Egypt ont rétrogradé à 4 1/3.
Parmi les petites valeurs, l& Delta Land al faibli à 8 8/8. Les Abdy ont été cotés 11/16 ox coupon. Les parts de fondateur Egyptian Land Investment and Building on é: 6 ra. moulées à 3 7/8.
Nous détachons d'ane lettre de Londres, en dato da 8 Mars, l'ıntéressant passage ci-après :

"Notre maroobé a été franchement mauvais cette semaine et les cours des valeurs égyptiennes sont en baisse sensible. Le recul est motivé par les ordres de vente reçus d'Egypte, ordres qui n'ont pu être exécuté entièrement, faute de contrepartie. L'opinion prévaut ici que le marché égyptien ressent les effets de la pléthore de nouvelles émissions : les nouveaux titres ne trouvant pas d'acquéreurs dans le public restent forcément à la charge des émetteurs, qui liquident les bonnes valeurs pour s'approvisionner des fonds nécessaires.

"Ioi, nous offrons également des nouvelles émissions pour les chemins de fer en Amérique, ce qui empêche une détente dans la situation monétaire et noog menace même d'un renchérissement du loyer de l'argent. La crise à li New York est persistante, et l'on craint que la Banque d'Angleterre de se voie obligée, pour protéger sa réserve, de recourir la semaine prochaine à une élévation de son taux d'escompte. Il est vrai que la loi Aldrich est! appelée à rendre prochainement quelque aisance au marché américain et à détourner les dangers que l'on appréhende de ce côté. Bo attendant, aq Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais, ainsi | que nos aatres fonde, baissent, et il est probable que cette dépression n'aura dit son dernier mot qne vers le 15 Mar 8, après la liquida. A tion de quinzaine. Il faudra s'attendre ensuite À une forte reprise, car le débat se à New York J agra pris fio d'ioi la."

L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Société. Anonyme da chemin de fer Keneh-A880dan a été tende avant-hier au siège social au Caire, Elle a approuvé les comptes de l'exercice 1906 et décidé la distribution de : 1°. Ua intérêt et dividende de P.E. 110,25 par action de capital; 2'. Un dividende de PE. 48 par action del v. jouissance ; 8o. Un dividende de P.E. 78.75 par part de fondateur, payables à partir du 20 Mars courant, à la National Bank of Egypt.

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)
div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
